Award.AwardTitle: Preparing Black Female Faculty for Prominence, Power, and Presence in the Academy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. This conference proposal focuses on developing a research agenda that will explore ways to help African American female faculty at predominantly white institutions navigate the promotion and tenure process. The conference will establish a platform for intergroup discussions about diversity in the workplace, illuminate gaps in existing literature to help target future research, and propose pathways for assisting African American faculty and graduate students succeed in the academy. The conference will involve nationally recognized education researchers from multiple STEM disciplines and academic institutions. The conference will help advance knowledge in the field by addressing gaps in research about the larger need to know what works, for whom, and why in academic settings where African American female faculty members often face deep-rooted challenges that threaten their continued participation in STEM fields.

The outcomes from this conference will potentially impact participating faculty members, conference presenters, education researchers, as well as the students they teach and mentor. The outcomes will include the development of a white paper that synthesizes current research and suggests what future research should entail. A network to support socialization will be established to link tenured African American female faculty with their graduate and undergraduate students to facilitate the sharing of experiences that fosters upward mobility in academic environments. Therefore, results from this conference will serve as a baseline for instituting pathways capable of forestalling negative encounters prevalent in higher education settings. The impact will reach across disciplines (STEM and the social sciences) and institutional types (predominantly white institutions, Historically Black Colleges and Universities, and community colleges) to increase the diversity and quality of the Nation's STEM workforce, which in turn, will help the United States maintain its status in a global society and marketplace. Specific strategies will be disseminated through offices of diversity and inclusion at the participating institutions as well as national and international professional education associations and societies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Preparing Black Female Faculty for Prominence, Power, and Presence in the Academy

(NSF 1651112) 

 Intellectual Merit

This conference focused on exploring ways to help African American female faculty at predominantly white institutions navigate the promotion and tenure process. Using Collin?s (2001) Black Feminist Thought theory, Ladson-Billing and Tate?s (1995) Critical Race Theory, and Kumashiro?s (2000) theory of the other as frameworks for the conference agenda, the conference established a platform for intergroup discussions about intersections of race, gender, and inequity in the academy. Conference evaluation results indicated that participants benefited from having a safe space to engage in dialogue with other Black women similarly situated in academia about daily challenges that impact their performance relative to teaching, research, and service. Also, participants expressed that the small number of attendees, the intimate setting, and the opportunity to engage in one-on-one interaction with speakers and other participants helped them to build supportive networks of Black women faculty within and outside of their academic area.

 A review of related literature that focused on empirically-based research using Black women faculty as the sample guided the project team in illuminating gaps in existing literature. To move beyond bringing the deeply-rooted challenges often faced by Black women faculty to the attention of others, the project team conducted empirically-based research that focused on problematizing systemic racism and the status of Black women faculty in the academy. Using a qualitative research design with focus groups, data were collected from three focus groups. A total of 18 participants participated in the focus groups. Participants taught in the STEM fields of engineering, mathematics, and science; and in education and communications. Purposive and snowball sampling techniques were used to select those who attended the conference. All participants who attended the conference were invited to participate in the focus groups. Each focus group was between 75- to 90-minutes. Data were audio recorded and transcribed verbatim. The researchers reviewed the transcripts at least three (3) times individually to identify common themes. Then the researchers read the transcripts collectively, and after organizing and reorganizing the commonalities, final categories of data were determined.  Data analysis revealed two main categories of themes?paid, public work and unpaid, private work, which were further broken down into more specific themes. Specifically, six themes related to paid/public work: Mentorship dilemmas, Mixed Messages, Invisible Work, Devaluing Research, Professional and Social Isolation, and Imposter Syndrome. Nuanced level analysis revealed that the lack of accountability or ineffective leadership for mentoring junior faculty contributed to mentoring dilemmas and the mixed messages that junior faculty received regarding their progress towards promotion and tenure. These findings contribute the existing literature by expanding the research about Black female faculty?s plight to gain promotion and tenure at predominantly White institutions by focusing specifically on Black female faculty; using the Black feminist thought theory as a theoretical framework; and by pointing toward the need for institutional accountability--the need for institutional leadership to play a more active role in ensuring that Black female faculty receive the quality socialization and mentoring experiences documented in the literature.

 Broader Impacts

This conference involved twenty-seven (27) Black women tenured-track faculty and nationally recognized education researchers from multiple STEM disciplines and academic institutions. This conference impacted these participating faculty members, conference presenters, education researchers, as well as the students they teach and mentor. These impacts reach across disciplines (STEM and the social sciences) and institutional types (predominantly White institutions, Historically Black Colleges and Universities, and community colleges) to increase the diversity and quality of the Nation?s STEM workforce, which in turn, will help the United States maintain its status in a global society and marketplace. The empirically-based research produced from this conference has been disseminated formally and informally. This research and information about the conference has been shared with the audiences of national and international professional education associations at three conferences, two journals, and one institution. A research manuscript has been submitted to a peer-reviewed journal and is currently under-review. Informally, research findings and strategies gleamed from these findings are shared through faculty social networks with individual faculty members and future faculty members on a regular basis.
